results.title: Discovering mood in music (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Through listening to various types of music the class discovers different ways that the composer has used to depict moods. Then they find that they can move in ways that reflect the moods of music and art.

results.title: Discovering melody and harmony (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Illustrates the movement and relationship of melody and harmony in music. Harmony is added to the melody through the use of descant and thirds and by playing instruments showing how both can move in repeats, steps or skips.
results.description: Illustrates the movement and relationship of melody and harmony in music. Harmony is added to the melody through the use of descant and thirds and by playing instruments showing how both can move in repeats, steps or skips.

results.title: Discovering jazz (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Traces the history of jazz from its roots in nineteenth century black America. Rhythmic and melodic freedom were added to the harmony and structure of European music, and techniques like note bending, call and response were added. Jazz soon became popular and its form progressed from dixie and blues through such styles as swing, bop, cool jazz, funky and free improvisation.

results.title: Discovering individual differences
results.brief_description: The methods by which a fifth-grade teacher becomes acquainted with the individual needs and characteristics of the children in her class, displayed in dramatised incidents. Shows how these techniques are successfully applied in five typical cases and how they might be generally used to supplement the teacher’s own experience and resourcefulness.

results.title: Discovering harmony in art
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and Paul Burnford Productions
results.brief_description: Harmony is a pleasing agreement in the things we hear, see, or do. Many things are harmonious in the world of nature. Harmony in art can be achieved in various ways. Firstly by limiting the number of objects, colors and shapes we use; secondly, by repeating objects, colors and shapes; thirdly, by using related objects, colors and shapes.

results.title: Discovering electronic music (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bernard Wilets and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Shows something of the physical basis of music and how it can be created and altered by electronic means. Demonstrates the sound synthesizer and its capacity to create, envelop and filter sound. Shows computer controlled music and a composition being created through the use of a computer.

results.title: Discovering color
results.brief_description: Three ways in which colors differ: hue, value and intensity. Hues as parts of the spectrum: red, orange, yellow, green, blue and violet. Between the basic hues are many in-between hues. The value of any hue may be lightened or darkened by adding white or black. The intensity of any hue can be lowered, or dulled, by adding its complementary hue. Techniques of color mixing: the great variety of color in the world around us.

results.title: Discover Australia's national parks
results.brief_description: Shows what to see and do in Australia’s National Parks, their location and the facilities available for visitors. This film shows Port Campbell, Wyperfeld, Mt. Buffalo and Wilson’s Promontory National Parks - all in Victoria. Narrated by Robert Raymond.

results.title: Discipline and self control (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: J Stone and National Audio Visual Center
results.brief_description: Discusses the problem of discipline as one of teaching and living with young children. Shows how a teacher can establish control in a friendly climate and prevent disciplinary problems; discusses adequate supervision, the dangers of over and under control and how to help a child accept control. Filmed at various schools in the United States.

results.title: Disaster fly
results.brief_description: If the screw fly entered Australia the cost to the cattle and sheep industries would be high. The screw worm fly is a danger to all warm-blooded animals, including man, and begins its cycle in flesh wounds. Papua New Guinea is the only screw worm-infected country near Australia, and it is pursuing research into control of this pest
